prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section.

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Revised paragraph:

vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits

prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap the manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text; these references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear with the format "[@TYPE:ID]" such as "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

Input paragraph: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Revised paragraph:

vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

response.output: Genes interact in networks to perform various functions, with their variations potentially impacting disease-relevant biological processes [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. Understanding how genes influence complex traits necessitates a mechanistic comprehension of expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9]. This understanding can lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous research has identified various regulatory DNA elements, including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/natu re14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data has enhanced the identification of transcriptional mechanisms, which when dysregulated, often result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/nc omm s6890; @pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. However, a more comprehensive understanding of these genetic associations and their implications for disease etiology and drug mechanisms remains elusive. This study aims to address this gap by projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns.

prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section.

Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

Revised paragraph:

vars.title: Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms
vars.keywords: genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
vars.content: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which may not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

response.output: In light of the extensive availability of gene expression data across numerous tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], a potent method to pinpoint these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). response.output:
Transcriptome-wide association studies (TWAS) have emerged as a powerful tool in understanding the genetic underpinnings of human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These studies operate by examining whether alterations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variants and diseases [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]. The success of TWAS extends beyond mere disease etiology comprehension at the transcriptome level, as it also aids in predicting disease risk through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and facilitates drug repurposing efforts [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

Given the abundance of gene expression data across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], TWAS offers an effective means to identify these biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, thereby providing a mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings. However, a significant limitation of TWAS is that it operates at the individual gene level, which inherently fails to capture more complex interactions occurring at the network level. This manuscript aims to address this knowledge gap by proposing an innovative approach to extend TWAS beyond single genes and into the realm of gene networks.

response.output:
Transcriptome-wide association studies (TWAS) have emerged as a powerful tool in understanding genetic associations with human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These studies investigate whether alterations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variants and diseases, providing valuable insights into disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]. Beyond disease understanding, TWAS have also been instrumental in predicting disease risk through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and repurposing drugs for novel therapeutic applications [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

Given the availability of gene expression data across multiple tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], TWAS integrate expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of genome-wide association studies (GWAS) findings. However, the current limitation of TWAS is its focus on individual genes, which fails to capture more complex interactions at the network level. This manuscript aims to address this knowledge gap by exploring gene co-expression patterns and clustering of complex traits, thereby enhancing our understanding of disease etiology and drug mechanisms for potential therapeutic targets and drug repurposing.

Given the availability of gene expression data across multiple tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], a powerful method for identifying the biological processes underlying these associations is TWAS, which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) data to provide mechanistic insights into genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings. However, as TWAS operates at the individual gene level, it may not fully capture more complex interactions occurring at the network level.

response.output:
Context: With the abundance of gene expression data spanning various tissues [[@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]], a powerful method for uncovering biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). This approach integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) data to offer an explanation behind genome-wide association studies (GWAS) findings.

Content: However, TWAS focuses on individual genes and fails to capture intricate interactions at the network level. It functions by examining whether alterations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate associations between genetic variants and human diseases [[@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]]. These methods have been highly effective in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]], predicting disease risk using polygenic scores [[@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w]], and repurposing drugs for new therapeutic uses [[@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]].

Conclusion: Despite these successes, TWAS's focus on individual genes leaves a gap in understanding complex network interactions, which is crucial for fully comprehending disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This manuscript aims to address this knowledge gap by projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns, thereby highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

vars.content: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

response.output: Given the abundance of gene expression data across multiple tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], a powerful method to uncover these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). This approach integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) data, offering mechanistic insights into genome-wide association studies (GWAS) findings [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. However, TWAS operates at the single gene level and may not fully capture complex network-level interactions. Despite this limitation, these methods have been instrumental in understanding disease etiology [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], predicting disease risk through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and repurposing drugs for new therapeutic applications [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. Nevertheless, there remains a need to explore more intricate gene interactions at the network level, which could further enhance our understanding of disease mechanisms and drug discovery efforts.

Has roughly the same length as input

prompt.raw:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap the manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text; these references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear with the format "[@TYPE:ID]" such as "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level. vars.content: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

response.output: In light of the abundance of gene expression data spanning multiple tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], a powerful method to pinpoint these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). TWAS incorporates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) data, offering mechanistic insights for genome-wide association studies (GWAS) results. Nevertheless, TWAS operates at an individual gene level, potentially overlooking intricate network interactions [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506]. This approach scrutinizes whether alterations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These methods have not only advanced our understanding of disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also contributed to disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, the current TWAS framework does not fully capture complex gene interactions at a network level, highlighting the need for more sophisticated approaches to unravel these relationships.

outputs.text: Genes collaborate in context-specific networks to carry out various functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can alter their functional roles and, at a higher level, impact disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, understanding how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically comprehending expression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies have described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/natura12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3], including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/ncammun6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

However, a more comprehensive understanding of these genetic associations and their implications for disease etiology and drug mechanisms remains elusive. This study aims to address this gap by projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns.

outputs.text: Genes collaborate in context-specific networks to execute various functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations within these genes can alter their functional roles and, consequently, impact disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, understanding how genes contribute to complex traits necessitates a mechanistic comprehension of expression regulation across diverse cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which should ultimately lead to enhanced treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous investigations have outlined various regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3], including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and genome-wide association study (GWAS) data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomm s6890] has improved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when disrupted, frequently result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathologies [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105]. However, a comprehensive understanding of how genetic associations can be projected through gene expression patterns to highlight disease etiology and drug mechanisms remains elusive. This manuscript aims to address this gap by leveraging the power of functional genomics and clustering of complex traits for potential therapeutic target discovery and drug repurposing.

vars.content: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,

}

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

score = 2.0

  "ekspression",
  "improoved",

]

vars: Genes work together in context-specific networks to karry out different functions [@pmid:19104045; @doi:10.1038/ng.3259]. Variations in these genes can change their functional role and, at a higher level, affect disease-relevant biological processes [@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-06022-6]. In this context, determining how genes influence complex traits requires mechanistically understanding ekspression regulation across different cell types [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3; @doi:10.1038/s41576-019-0200-9], which in turn should lead to improved treatments [@doi:10.1038/ng.3314; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1008489]. Previous studies has described different regulatory DNA elements [@doi:10.1038/nature11247; @doi:10.1038/nature14248; @doi:10.1038/nature12787; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03145-z; @doi:10.1038/s41586-020-2559-3] including genetic effects on gene expression across different tissues [@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776]. Integrating functional genomics data and GWAS data [@doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1016/j.ajhg.2018.04.002; @doi:10.1038/s41588-018-0081-4; @doi:10.1038/ncomms6890] has improoved the identification of these transcriptional mechanisms that, when dysregulated, commonly result in tissue- and cell lineage-specific pathology [@pmid:20624743; @pmid:14707169; @doi:10.1073/pnas.0810772105].

Has no spelling errors
Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms

outputs.text: Given the availability of gene expression data across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], a powerful approach to identify these biological processes is the transcriptome-wide association study (TWAS). TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association studies (GWAS) findings. This method tests whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These approaches have been highly successful in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and have also been instrumental in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which may not capture more complex interactions at the network level.
outputs.prompt:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript. Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section.

Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

Revised paragraph:

assertion.value: Doesn't reference authors, keywords, introduction, etc
Has roughly the same length as input
Keeps most references to other articles
Does not make up references to other articles

outputs.text: In light of the extensive availability of gene expression data across numerous tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], a potent method to pinpoint these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). This approach integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, thereby offering a mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association studies (GWAS) findings [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS operates by examining whether alterations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases. Such methods have not only been instrumental in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. Nevertheless, TWAS primarily focuses on individual genes, potentially overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level. Therefore, there is a need for approaches that can capture these complex gene-gene interactions to provide a more comprehensive understanding of disease etiology and potential therapeutic targets.

Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

Revised paragraph:

assertion.value: Doesn't reference authors, keywords, introduction, etc
Has roughly the same length as input
Keeps most references to other articles
Does not make up references to other articles

outputs.text: In light of the abundance of gene expression data spanning multiple tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], one effective method to pinpoint these biological processes is the transcriptome-wide association study (TWAS). This approach integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) data, offering a mechanistic explanation for genome-wide association studies (GWAS) findings [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS operates by examining whether alterations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases. These methods have been instrumental not only in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in predicting disease risk (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and repurposing drugs for treatment [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS primarily focuses on individual genes, thereby overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level. This limitation underscores a significant gap in our understanding of complex genetic associations and their implications for disease etiology and drug mechanisms.
outputs.prompt:
You are a scientist with copy-editing skills tasked with refining the text of a scientific manuscript titled 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' with keywords 'genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits.' Your goal is to revise the following paragraph from the Introduction section to enhance clarity, reduce jargon, and maintain a scholarly tone. The revision should adhere to Markdown formatting and follow a Context-Content-Conclusion (C-C-C) structure. This structure begins by setting the stage with one or two sentences (Context), progresses through what is known from the literature (Content), and concludes by highlighting an aspect of the knowledge gap the manuscript addresses (Conclusion). Your revision should: 1) preserve the original information as much as possible, with minimal changes to the text, 2) ensure most references to scientific articles are kept exactly as they appear in the original text; these references are crucial for academic integrity and may appear with the format "[@TYPE:ID]" such as "[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]", and 4) the revised paragraph must encapsulate the entire revision, following the C-C-C structure, within a single, cohesive paragraph.

However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, offering a mechanistic explanation for genome-wide association studies (GWAS) findings [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. assert.value:
description = "Doesn't reference authors, keywords, introduction, etc"
type = "Formatting"
score = 0.25

keywords = [
  "authors",
  "Introduction:",
  "Keywords:",
  "References:",
]
res = not any(kw in output for kw in keywords)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

description = "Has roughly the same length as input"
type = "Formatting"
score = 0.25

input = context["vars"]["content"]
input_words = len(input.strip().split())
output_words = len(output.strip().split())

res = (output_words > 0.5 * input_words) and (output_words < 1.5 * input_words)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

  "@pmid:31036433",

  "@doi:10.1038/nn.4618",
}

# keep only references that are present in the input (this is needed because
#  references might be removed from the input in some cases)
references = [ref for ref in references if ref in input]

count = len([ref for ref in references if ref in output])
res = (count / len(references) > 0.50)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

references = {

# keep only references that are present in the input (this is needed because

# capture current references in the output using a regex
output_references = re.findall(r'@[^ ;\]]+', output)

outputs.text: In light of the abundance of gene expression data spanning multiple tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], a potent method to uncover these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). TWAS incorporates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) data to elucidate the mechanistic basis of genome-wide association studies (GWAS) findings [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These methods have been instrumental in deciphering disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and have also shown promise in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] as well as drug repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, thereby overlooking more intricate interactions occurring at the network level. This limitation underscores a significant gap in our understanding of complex trait clustering and disease etiology, which this manuscript aims to address by projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns.

outputs.text:
Failed
---
Transcriptome-wide association studies (TWAS) have emerged as a powerful tool in understanding the genetic underpinnings of human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These studies operate by examining whether alterations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variants and diseases [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]. The success of TWAS extends beyond mere disease etiology comprehension at the transcriptome level, as it also aids in predicting disease risk through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and facilitates drug repurposing efforts [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

Given the abundance of gene expression data across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], TWAS offers an effective means to identify these biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, thereby providing a mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings. However, a significant limitation of TWAS is that it operates at the individual gene level, which inherently fails to capture more complex interactions occurring at the network level. This manuscript aims to address this knowledge gap by proposing an innovative approach to extend TWAS beyond single genes and into the realm of gene networks.

outputs.text:
Failed
---
Transcriptome-wide association studies (TWAS) have emerged as a powerful tool in understanding genetic associations with human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These studies investigate whether alterations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variants and diseases, providing valuable insights into disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]. Beyond disease understanding, TWAS have also been instrumental in predicting disease risk through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and repurposing drugs for novel therapeutic applications [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

Given the availability of gene expression data across multiple tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], TWAS integrate expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) data to offer a mechanistic interpretation of genome-wide association studies (GWAS) findings. However, the current limitation of TWAS is its focus on individual genes, which fails to capture more complex interactions at the network level. This manuscript aims to address this knowledge gap by exploring gene co-expression patterns and clustering of complex traits, thereby enhancing our understanding of disease etiology and drug mechanisms for potential therapeutic targets and drug repurposing.

vars.content: TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks. Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level.

assert.value:
description = "Doesn't reference authors, keywords, introduction, etc"
type = "Formatting"
score = 0.25

keywords = [
  "authors",
  "Introduction:",
  "Keywords:",
  "References:",
]
res = not any(kw in output for kw in keywords)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

description = "Has roughly the same length as input"
type = "Formatting"
score = 0.25

input = context["vars"]["content"]
input_words = len(input.strip().split())
output_words = len(output.strip().split())

res = (output_words > 0.5 * input_words) and (output_words < 1.5 * input_words)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

description = "Starts with context"
type = "Structure"
full_score = 2.0
reason = "Failed"

# make sure TWAS is spelled out in the first two sentences
first_two_sentences = ". ".join(output.split(". ")[:2]).lower()

res = "transcription-wide association stud" in first_two_sentences
if res:
  reason = "Passed (full score)"
  score = full_score
else:
  res = "transcriptome-wide association stud" in first_two_sentences
  if res:
    reason = "Passed (half score)"
    score = full_score / 2.0

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": reason,
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

outputs.text: Transcriptome-Wide Association Studies (TWAS) rely on assessing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the Transcriptome-Wide Association Study (TWAS). outputs.text: Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) have emerged as a powerful tool in genetic research, leveraging perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms to elucidate associations between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These approaches have not only enhanced our understanding of disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also facilitated disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. With the growing availability of gene expression data across multiple tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], TWAS, which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, provides a mechanistic interpretation for genome-wide association studies (GWAS) findings. However, the current limitations of TWAS lie in its focus on individual genes, thereby overlooking more intricate interactions at the network level.

outputs.text: The transcription-wide association study (TWAS), a methodology that tests whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], has been instrumental in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] as well as drug repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. This knowledge gap highlights the need for methodologies that can effectively analyze and interpret these intricate genetic relationships.

outputs.text: In the context of extensive gene expression data across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as a powerful tool for identifying biological processes by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide mechanistic interpretations for genome-wide association studies (GWAS) findings. outputs.text: In light of the abundance of gene expression data spanning various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], a powerful method for identifying these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). Nevertheless, the challenge remains to develop methods that can effectively model these complex gene regulatory networks for a more comprehensive understanding of disease mechanisms.

vars.content: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

assert.value:
description = "Doesn't reference authors, keywords, introduction, etc"
type = "Formatting"
score = 0.25

keywords = [
  "authors",
  "Introduction:",
  "Keywords:",
  "References:",
]
res = not any(kw in output for kw in keywords)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

description = "Has roughly the same length as input"
type = "Formatting"
score = 0.25

input = context["vars"]["content"]
input_words = len(input.strip().split())
output_words = len(output.strip().split())

res = (output_words > 0.5 * input_words) and (output_words < 1.5 * input_words)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

description = "Ends with conclusion"
type = "Structure"
score = 2.0

# get last two sentences
last_sentences = ". ".join(output.split(". ")[-2:]).lower()

keywords = [
  "however",
  "nevertheless",
  "nonetheless",
  "limitation",
  "despite",
  "though",
  "even though",
]

res = any(k in last_sentences for k in keywords)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level and does not capture more complex interactions at the network level. These approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

Failed
---
In the era of abundant gene expression data across numerous tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], the transcription-wide association study (TWAS) has emerged as a powerful tool to unravel underlying biological processes. By integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data, TWAS offers mechanistic insights into genome-wide association studies (GWAS) findings [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. However, TWAS primarily operates at the individual gene level, potentially overlooking intricate interactions at the network level. Despite this limitation, TWAS has been instrumental in understanding disease etiology [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] and predicting disease risk through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w]. Moreover, it has shown promise in drug repurposing tasks [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618], highlighting its versatility and potential for further advancements in the field of functional genomics. The manuscript 'Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms' aims to address this knowledge gap by exploring complex trait clustering, thereby providing a more comprehensive understanding of disease etiology and therapeutic targets.

outputs.text:
Failed
---
Context: With the abundance of gene expression data spanning various tissues [[@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]], a powerful method for uncovering biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). This approach integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) data to offer an explanation behind genome-wide association studies (GWAS) findings.

Content: However, TWAS focuses on individual genes and fails to capture intricate interactions at the network level. It functions by examining whether alterations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate associations between genetic variants and human diseases [[@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]]. These methods have been highly effective in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [[@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]], predicting disease risk using polygenic scores [[@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w]], and repurposing drugs for new therapeutic uses [[@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]].

Conclusion: Despite these successes, TWAS's focus on individual genes leaves a gap in understanding complex network interactions, which is crucial for fully comprehending disease etiology and drug mechanisms. This manuscript aims to address this knowledge gap by projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns, thereby highlighting disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

vars.content: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

assert.value:
description = "Doesn't reference authors, keywords, introduction, etc"
type = "Formatting"
score = 0.25

keywords = [
  "authors",
  "Introduction:",
  "Keywords:",
  "References:",
]
res = not any(kw in output for kw in keywords)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

description = "Has roughly the same length as input"
type = "Formatting"
score = 0.25

input = context["vars"]["content"]
input_words = len(input.strip().split())
output_words = len(output.strip().split())

res = (output_words > 0.5 * input_words) and (output_words < 1.5 * input_words)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

description = "Ends with conclusion"
type = "Structure"
score = 2.0

# get last two sentences
last_sentences = ". ".join(output.split(". ")[-2:]).lower()

keywords = [
  "however",
  "nevertheless",
  "nonetheless",
  "limitation",
  "despite",
  "though",
  "even though",
]

res = any(k in last_sentences for k in keywords)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

Input paragraph: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

assertion.value: Doesn't reference authors, keywords, introduction, etc

outputs.text: Given the abundance of gene expression data across various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], a powerful method to uncover these biological processes is the transcriptome-wide association study (TWAS). TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) data, thereby offering a mechanistic understanding of genome-wide association studies (GWAS) findings [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. However, TWAS primarily focuses on individual genes and may not fully capture complex interactions at the network level. Despite this limitation, TWAS has been instrumental in understanding disease etiology [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], predicting disease risk through polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and repurposing drugs for therapeutic use [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. Nonetheless, there remains a need to expand our understanding of complex gene interactions in disease etiology and drug mechanisms.

TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

outputs.text: In light of the abundance of gene expression data spanning multiple tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], a powerful method for identifying biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) data to offer mechanistic insights into genome-wide association studies (GWAS) findings [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.

assert.value:
description = "Doesn't reference authors, keywords, introduction, etc"
type = "Formatting"
score = 0.25

keywords = [
  "authors",
  "Introduction:",
  "Keywords:",
  "References:",
]
res = not any(kw in output for kw in keywords)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

description = "Has roughly the same length as input"
type = "Formatting"
score = 0.25

input = context["vars"]["content"]
input_words = len(input.strip().split())
output_words = len(output.strip().split())

res = (output_words > 0.5 * input_words) and (output_words < 1.5 * input_words)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

description = "Ends with conclusion"
type = "Structure"
score = 2.0

# get last two sentences
last_sentences = ". ".join(output.split(". ")[-2:]).lower()

keywords = [
  "however",
  "nevertheless",
  "nonetheless",
  "limitation",
  "despite",
  "though",
  "even though",
]

res = any(k in last_sentences for k in keywords)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

vars: Given the availability of gene expression data across several tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective approach to identify these biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS), which integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide a mechanistic interpretation for GWAS findings. However, TWAS works at the individual gene level, which does not capture more complex interactions at the network level. TWAS relies on testing whether perturbations in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the association between genetic variants and human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367], and these approaches have been highly successful not only in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433] but also in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618] tasks.
genetic studies, functional genomics, gene co-expression, therapeutic targets, drug repurposing, clustering of complex traits
ends with conclusion
Projecting genetic associations through gene expression patterns highlights disease etiology and drug mechanisms

vars.test_description: Keeps most references to other articles and doesn't make them up
vars.title: file://./inputs/title.txt
vars.keywords: file://./inputs/keywords.txt
vars.content: file://./inputs/has_references_to_articles.md

assert.value:
description = "Keeps most references to other articles"
type = "Information accuracy"
score = 2.0

input = context["vars"]["content"]

references = {
  "@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838",
  "@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6",
  "@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776",
  "@doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9",
  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482",
  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3506",
  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889",
  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3367",
  "@pmid:33931583",
  "@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225",
  "@pmid:31036433",
  "@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w",
  "@doi:10.1038/nn.4618",
}

# keep only references that are present in the input (this is needed because
#  references might be removed from the input in some cases)
references = [ref for ref in references if ref in input]

count = len([ref for ref in references if ref in output])
res = (count / len(references) > 0.50)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}

description = "Does not make up references to other articles"
type = "Information accuracy"
score = 2.0

import re

input = context["vars"]["content"]

references = {
  "@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838",
  "@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6",
  "@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776",
  "@doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9",
  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482",
  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3506",
  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889",
  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3367",
  "@pmid:33931583",
  "@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225",
  "@pmid:31036433",
  "@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w",
  "@doi:10.1038/nn.4618",
}

# keep only references that are present in the input (this is needed because
#  references might be removed from the input in some cases)
references = [ref for ref in references if ref in input]

# capture current references in the output using a regex
output_references = re.findall(r'@[^ ;\]]+', output)

n_fake_refs = len([ref for ref in output_references if ref not in references])
res = (n_fake_refs == 0)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}
